text: From a ceiling angle, right up against a buzzing, occasionally flickering overhead BULB -- A MAN in this cluttered office paces back and forth. On the phone. This is PAUL, 40s, a man with gentle eyes whose body cann hide symptoms of stress and exhaustion. Deeply concerned.

I’ve tried that. She won't go. Windows in the office look out on a larger warehouse, ful racks of clothing, mannequins, and bins of coat hangers. Paul flicks through pages on a web browser as he stands a his desk, switching the phone to the other ear.

Rebecca? She’s her own train wreck. And I see her maybe once a year. I can’t expect her to help us. Paul listens to the person on the other end of the call. Nods along as if he agrees with them. All the while, he absently toys with his wedding band on ring finger with his thumb.
Yeah. Yeah, okay. A light clicks ON in the warehouse, and a young man named KEITH (20s) crosses through an aisle to the office door. He knocks and enters, holding a tablet--
Okay, so-- (notices phone) Oop. Paul covers the mouthpiece with his hand.
Inventory good? Keith holds up the tablet, an app glowing on its screen.
More overages from J-Four. None of it is “Fall Collection.” They're still treating us like a dumping ground for that failed line.

Ship it back. (into phone) I hear you. I’m not saying it isn’t a tough call. Keith mouths the word: “Tonight?” Paul sees the plea in Keith’s eyes and waves him off. Mouths back, “Tomorrow.” Keith puts his hands together and bows at Paul, then leav shutting the door quietly behind him.

(into phone) We switched HMOs last month, and getting the prescription sorted has been a pain. So she’s been off her meds and now I keep... It’s just rough. I haven’t slept much. The motion-activated warehouse light clicks OFF. The cavernous space outside the office is dark. Nothing b black shapes huddled together.

You and Craig were at our wedding. She will listen to you. Get her to stop locking herself in the closet. (then) So we don’t call it an intervention. Thank you, Donna. I‘’1l be home in the next hour. See you both then? (beat) All right. Bye. He hangs up. And his attention is drawn to that wallpaper
(sotto) Help is on the way. It’s unclear whom in the family photo he’s saying it to. With a WINK, the PC powers down.

The square MOTION-ACTIVATED SENSOR tucked high in a corne clicks, its red detection-light winking off-- And the warehouse lights sputter to life again. Paul locks the back office. His keys jangle. He makes his way toward the storefront. Traversing an aisle of dresses hanging on racks. Something CLATTERS in one distant corner. Paul pauses. Listening. Looking.
Keith? You still here? Silence. Paul stands on tiptoes to peer over the racks. No movement. The lights click OFF. Paul turns around, staring up at the motion activator.

(sotto) Oh, come on. He waves his arm at it. Trying to trigger it. Behind him, at the end of the aisle, a DARK SILHOUETTE s out from between the racks of clothes. It seems tall. With long, unkempt hair that disguises the shape of its head and neck. And oddly, it doesn’t seem to be wearing clothes. Its sha is too smooth; too raw. Paul isn’t aware of it. THE MOTION SENSOR still doesn’t wink on. In the dark, its small red ‘detection’ light glows wanly. PAUL waves with bigger gestures... And the SILHOUETTE advances for him... Slowly at first, then picking up speed, then THE LIGHTS c on again, sputtering to life-- And there is no one else in the aisle besides Paul. Paul turns around-- And notices the hanging dresses a few feet from him swayi as if brushed by someone’s shoulder.
Hello? No answer. Paul hurries for the door.
Paul rolls the metal security gate down on the front entr to the clothing storefront. Locks the gate with his keys.

The mall is quiet as a museum at night. It must be October, because Halloween decorations are out Ghosts and bats hanging on fishing wire. Scarecrows amid hay bales. Witches with pointy hats posed over kiosks. The whole place is dimly lit, mostly shut down. It’s cle Paul was working past closing time. No other shops are li Not even the hallway. Just the shelf lighting under the planters, and the occasional kiosk lights, showcasing some ad or mall map. Paul makes his way for the parking garage. As he passes a kiosk-- His SHADOW is cast upon the wall beside him. Advancing as continues past, stretching at a slanted angle. And a SECOND shadow advances just behind it. That same silhouette. Paul catches sight of it, and turns-- Nothing’s there. Nothing to make that shadow on the wall. He looks again at the wall-- It’s just his own shadow, and a very faint secondary one could be another shadow of his cast by a separate lamp. Paul’s phone RINGS. Startles the hell out of him. Nerves rattled, he checks the screen: “Home”
(answers) Hello? (then) Hey, kiddo. I’m coming home now. Promise I‘’ll be there soon. Paul picks up the pace as he talks to his son.
(into phone) How’s mom doing tonight? (beat) Yeah? Better? Paul reaches the doors to the parking garage. One last look back: All is quiet. All is still.
(into phone) Well I’m on my way.

When the sliding doors open for Paul, a sodium-vapor lamp awakens, saturating the structure in a dirty amber tint. This garage isn’t a typical parking building. Someone tri to make it look “arty” with its concrete pilings, turning sharp corners into rounded ends, and elongating support b in logarithmic curves. But at night, the effect is eerie: It looks like you’re inside the ribcage of an enormous Giger-esque monster. Paul’s Toyota sedan is one of maybe three cars still park at this hour, a hundred feet from the doors. Paul marches for it, keys in one hand, phone in the other It is a long and tense walk. Paul keeps looking around fo signs of other people. His footsteps echo in the cavernous space. Paul gets to the Toyota, unlocking it with his key fob. Behind him, the sodium-vapor security light goes out, drenching the garage in darkness. Paul opens the driver's door, grateful for the car’s inte light which casts a downward glow on the area around it. He hears something: The sound of the building doors slidi Paul turns around, unnerved, because the amber security l did not wink on this time. At the glass doors to the mall: THE SILHOUETTE.

Who’s there? Silence. Paul leans in, the Toyota squeaking from the weight of hi body. He grabs a flashlight from his glovebox and stands again at the door. His fight-or-flight feelings battle hi stubborn need to not be bullied or pranked. He clicks on the flashlight’s bright, narrow beam. Shines right at the silhouette-- And it’s GONE. Like the light erased it from existence. Paul frowns. Confused. Bordering on panic. He lowers the of light, shining it on his feet-- And the silhouette has returned. Thirty feet closer. Paul lifts the light again. Directing it at the shadow-fo Again: Just light and garage wall in the distance. Beat. Paul lowers the flashlight beam-- And the silhouette is A DOZEN FEET AWAY. Paul jumps-- emits a partial curse word, and brings that light beam up reflexively. Protectively. Once again, nothing. But now, he hears it. Feet scuffling on the ground. Hurrying in some direction. Paul sweeps the beam left and right, in search of it. Nothing. Then: a slight sound behind him. The Toyota squeaking as something leans against it. Paul looks down. A shadow is cast from the car’s interior light: Something is standing right behind him. Paul starts to whirl around but-- The flashlight shines in our eyes as some hint of a HAND grabs his wrist and-- Another dark-as-ink CLAWED HAND reaches around and covers mouth and-- THE FLASHLIGHT crashes to the ground, breaking.
Darkness. Then the sodium-vapor lamp awakens again, revea Paul’s mangled body on the ground by his car.

A montage of photographs -- family photos, vacation snapshots, candids from different times around the world.  In each of them, somewhere, is a vague, humanoid SHADOW. Unattached to any of the people. Sometimes it’s almost a smudge on the photo. In many, it’s distinct; lurking.

Malicious shadows cover a terrified, gorgeous woman trapp in a tomb. PULLING BACK to reveal it’s the cover art for a DEATH MET album of some Scandinavian band. Somewhere, heavy metal MUSIC plays on low volume.

INT. BEDROOM —- NIGHT More posters of metal bands, artwork from cult comic book Crappy furniture. A single bed with disheveled sheets, currently occupied by a young COUPLE: REBECCA (20s) and BRET (20s) share a cigarette, staring a the ceiling. Her dark lipstick is smeared, smudges of it apparent on Bret’s face and neck. Rebecca looks like a “Suicide Girl.” A Gothic tattoo “sle covers her left arm. Ears, nose, and lip sport piercings. hair and makeup are inspired by the character Death from Gaiman’s Sandman series. Bret’s bare chest showcases a few tattoos, and his hands rough and calloused from years of heavy guitar playing, b where Rebecca’s body language says “cool as ice,” his is bright and bouncy as a puppy. From the bedroom window, an outdoor neon sign for a restaurant winks on and off every few seconds.
Give me twenty minutes. I want another ride.
(rolls eyes) Uh-huh. I’m gonna go shower.
Oh yeah. Sure. Maybe I'11 join you.  She grins at Bret as she climbs out of bed.
You'll smell like girly soap. He smiles back. Completely smitten.
Rebecca showers. All that makeup washes out. The teased h thoroughly rinsed. No sign of Bret.

In a towel, Rebecca combs out her hair, staring at her ow reflection. Her skin is pink from the hot water. Now it’s clear how m of that makeup is a persona; a disguise. Because she look completely different in this light. She’s like a lost gir five years younger. She examines her left arm, with the elaborate tattoo. The inside of her forearm is more heavily inked. As if to cover over an older tattoo or birthmark. She looks at her right arm, currently bare. The inside of this arm is peppered with neat rows of shor scars. Too neat to be accidental. Rebecca used to be a cutter. For a brief moment, there’s a sadness in her expression rarely seen by someone twice her age. Then, she walls it up again in a deep breath, and steps out. INT. BEDROOM —- NIGHT It’s raining outside, now. Watersnake shadows slink down window, and the rain creates a soothing white noise. Bret is fast asleep on the bed. Snoring lightly. Rebecca nudges him with her naked foot.
Hey. Marathon Man.  10. He wakes up. Sits up on his elbows.
I’m up, I’m up. Rebecca goes to a drawer and pulls on an oversized t-shir Her putter-around-the-pad comfort wear.
You can’t stay. That’s when it hits us: This isn’t Bret’s apartment. It’s Rebecca’s. All this artwork is hers.
Aww, Becca. Just one night?
Nope. Bret reluctantly starts to get dressed. Notices the weath
You're kicking me out in the rain?
You'll be fine. You’re not a puppy.
I thought I was your boyfriend.
You're a guy I’ve been seeing. (off his reaction) The only guy I’ve been seeing.
For eight months.

Eight months? Really? Wow. That puts you in first place. (then) C’mon, out, I have work early in the morning. Then I’m gonna have Gina start on my other sleeve. Rebecca shuffles out the door to her living room.
(calling after) I can’t even keep a pair of jeans here?  ll.
No.
Not even a sock? Just one sock!
What good is one sock?
Is that a yes?
No. Bret pulls a t-shirt over his head. It sports a band logo his own thrash metal band -- UNHOLY TRINITY. With a peeli photo-graphic of himself and his two bandmates.
Rebecca cleans up the Chinese takeout on the coffee table This place is too small to have a dining room. Bret calls from the bedroom:
It’s not like having a sock here would make it impossible to get rid of me. Socks are not anchors. Rebecca sighs.
I'll see you tomorrow night at the gig. Let’s just agree to that, OK?
Bret goes to her top drawer and drops one sock in among h collection of bras and panties.

All right. He puts his boots on. Hiding his one bare foot. EXT. REBECCA’S FRONT STOOP - NIGHT Bret steps out, protected under a small awning.  12. The rain has gotten heavier. Rebecca kisses him, smiles, then shuts the door. Beat. Bret shakes his head, grinning.
I love you, too! Reluctantly, he steps out into the weather. Makes his way down the sidewalk. Pauses, fishing for his car keys.
Hey! Sexy! Bret looks up through the rain: Rebecca has slid open her bedroom window, grinning down a him, still in her t-shirt.
I like you a lot. Bret steps forward, encouraged.
Is that all?
Not quite. Bret smiles through the rain. Expectant. His SOCK sails down and lands on his shoulder.
See you tomorrow. She slides the window shut. Bret picks his drenched sock from his shoulder.
(sotto) So close...  13.

Grinning like a girl in love, Rebecca saunters back into room and crosses the fireplace, leaning down to turn up t music in here. SLOWLY PUSHING IN on a photo gathering dust on the mantle A much younger Sophie, and a 12-year-old REBECCA together Snapped in mid-laugh, Sophie surprised by her daughter. No sign of Paul or Martin here.
And then a shadow passes over it, and suddenly it’s not a dusty as it was-- PULLING BACK to reveal--

INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Another mantle, this one littered with framed photos. Next to the identical photo of Sophie and Rebecca: that p of Paul, Sophie, and Martin seen earlier on his computer. The collection showcases Martin most of all, but little Rebecca is there quite a lot, too. And then there’s PAUL. Center-stage on the mantle. A hand portrait... Next to his framed OBITUARY, dated two weeks earlier. INT. MARTIN’S ROOM - NIGHT Martin sits up in bed, still under the covers. He listens. He stares at his bedroom door. It hangs open a crack. He can hear murmured conversation, as if someone is on th phone down the hall. Martin makes a face -- his struggle to be brave plays out his body language -- and then he hops out of bed.  14.
Martin steps into the hall and travels past the upstairs bathroom to another door at the far end. The master bedroom. Half-closed. Martin can hear his mother’s voice in the room.

(small) Mommy? Martin pushes the door open... revealing... INT. SOPHIE’S BEDROOM A nest of clothes, empty glasses and stray plateware. Thi a hoarder’s room. In one corner, the light from the master bathroom offers crease of light into this otherwise dreary, dark space. In the other corner, SOPHIE stands at the open doorway to master closet, in profile, muttering to herself. She looks worse than in those photos. The manic is full-b here. Her hair frazzled. Her nails chewed.
I just don’t know what to do about it. And I’m sorry. I really am.
Mommy? Sophie turns to face Martin, surprised by him.
Yes, Martin?
(beat) Are you okay?
I will be. Just not there yet. Did we wake you? Martin tenses at that pluralization.
What?  15.

Go back to bed, sweetie. Only ones wandering the halls at this hour should be grown-ups. Sophie stares tiredly at her son. Gives him a slight nod “Go on, now.” Martin turns around, takes two steps back for his room...

(sotto) I know. But he means well. Martin looks back, over his shoulder. Sophie’s returned to looking into the closet... Where a SHADOW SLIDES along the door -- could it be cast Sophie herself? -- And then some floorboard CREAKS inside the closet. Martin’s breath catches. His nostrils flare. He hurries back down the hall, for his door-- INT. MARTIN’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS --rushing in and shutting the door behind him. Locking it Climbing into bed. Tense, expectant, he stares at his door. Beat. Nothing happens. Martin begins to calm down. CLICK. The hall light goes out. Martin holds his breath. From down the hall: the SOUND of bare feet thumping on th hardwood floor, with the added CLICKING of long nails. Right up to Martin’s bedroom door. Martin grips his blanket like a Spartan’s shield. A tense beat. Quiet.
.. -Mommy?  16. SCRATCHING on the door. Like a cat. THE DOORKNOB jiggles. From way farther down the hall, deep in Sophie’s room:
You want a kiss goodnight? Martin’s reply is swift and loud:

THE DOORKNOB stops jiggling. But there is no sound of receding footsteps. Martin slowly sinks under the covers, looking up at his nightstand lamp. THE BULB burns steadily. HANGING on that bulb, PRESSING IN... did it weaken? Did i just flicker? ON MARTIN, settling in for another sleepless night... INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - DAY The land-line phone RINGS. One of those old-fashioned, lo bell tones. No one answers. PULLING BACK, sunlight pierces through the window. Wide o It’s the next day. The phone stops RINGING. A beat later-- Sophie enters from the garage, carrying a shopping bag. She moves to the big bay window in the living room... And pulls out a heavy fabric from the bag. She bought some brand new curtains. To keep the sun out. EXT. MARTIN’S GRADE SCHOOL - DAY Establishing.  17.
(pre-lap) She isn’t answering.
Principal Fuller (40s, snappy dresser) moves around his d and approaches a couch on the other side of his office. Martin has dozed off. Fuller nudges him gently.
Hey. Martin? Martin wakes, tense. Blinks. PRINCIPAL FULLER (CONT’D) Is there someone else we could call for you? Martin considers the question.
Rebecca marches in from outside, with Bret trailing her. grins at the seasonal calendar for the grade school.
I didn’t know you had a brother. Rebecca makes a bee-line for the principal’s office. Before she enters:
Are you Rebecca? Rebecca wheels around to find EMMA (30s, sincere) waiting her, outside the door to the school nurse’s station.
Who are you?
I’m Emma. I’m with Child Services. (off her look) I was assigned to Martin after your father’s death last month, and--
Step-father.  18.
Excuse me?
Paul was Martin’s father, not mine. My dad ran off with his physical therapist when I was ten. Emma wasn’t expecting this information. She rolls with it

I don’t live there.

Yeah?
How is she holding up?
Well, she takes antidepressants for her mood swings. Is that what you're asking? Emma opens a small Moleskine notebook and makes a note.
How bad is it? The depression. Rebecca doesn’t like the notebook.
Nothing to write about.
Is it a chemical deficiency?
What?
Genetic?
No. I mean, I don’t know?
But you don’t live with her anymore, so can’t speak to her current behavior.
Look, is Martin okay? You’re talking like he has a black eye or something.

You showed up.
Yeah.

Where’s Mom? Martin shrugs. Looks away. Emma steps in, putting her notebook back in her

Martin. I know you and your mother are going through a lot. And it’s harder for you, because you really can’t talk to your mother about it. She's fighting her own battles. Rebecca rolls her eyes. She’s sat through these

bag. talks.

(right at Rebecca) This is why you left, isn’t it. 20. This gives Emma pause. She looks to Rebecca. Rebecca shru

Your home? Or mom's?
Where you live. Martin lets out a tired breath and eases off the chair. Rebecca can read his body language.

You’re gonna be okay. (to Emma) He’s gonna be fine. EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - DAY Bret’s beat-up SUV pulls into the driveway. INT. BRET’S SUV Bret shifts into park and smiles through the rearview Martin, who’s buckled into the back seat. Rebecca rides shotgun.
Here we are.
Her car is here, so she’s home. at Martin makes no move to unbuckle his seat belt. His backp sits on the seat next to him.  21.
You should take me to your place instead. Just for a night. Rebecca looks back at Martin. Bret chuckles.
Good luck barking up that tree. Rebecca gives Bret a “don’t start” glance, then tells Mar
You wouldn’t like it there. I have lots of scary posters on the walls. But Martin looks more scared of his own house now.
(sotto) I just need some sleep.
This is exciting.
Why are you excited?
Getting to meet your mom is a big deal. That's like, the next step. Rebecca rolls her eyes and opens her door.
C’mon Martin, let’s go. (points at Bret) You, stay in the car.
Oh come on. I wore my good jeans! Bret’s jeans: Patched and shredded.
Rebecca leads Martin up to the front door.
Mom goes through phases like this. Just give her a while and she'll bounce back. Is she being social with anyone right now?  22.
Someone keeps coming over.
Good. Who?
“Diana.” This stops Rebecca in her tracks. She turns to face Marti Her whole body language has changed now. Her hands make f at her sides. Her jaw pulses.
...What?
Her name is Diana. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM POV ANGLE: Watching Rebecca and Martin through a crack in curtains. Is this Sophie watching? Rebecca bends slightly to speak in low tones with Martin.
I know what you’re going through. She did it to me after my dad left. She got off her meds and started talking to... someone.
Rebecca puts a hand on Martin’s shoulder.

I had bad dreams about Diana, but that’s all they are. Because she isn’t real. Okay? Martin's face goes from hopeful confidant to disappointed Suddenly he looks more exhausted than any eight-year-old should ever be. Head bowed:
If you say so. The door opens and Sophie steps out, in a bath robe.  23.
Becca? Is that you? Rebecca stands up and approaches Sophie.
Hey, mom. Sophie notes Rebecca’s clothing color choice.
Still in mourning?
I just like black. Sophie nods, conceding. She pulls Rebecca into a welcome
It’s good to see you. It takes a moment for Rebecca to hug back. Didn’t expect
You, too. Martin moves past, into the house.
What are you doing home, little mister?
Martin doesn’t look back, he just marches for his bedroom Over his shoulder:
She’1l tell you.
He hasn’t been sleeping.
Who can blame him. Paul was everything to us. (corrects) Nearly everything.
Are you seeing a therapist? Sophie deflects by idly tidying up. As she does:  24.
I’m not going to talk about my problems to some stranger. I’ve been through this before. You were there when Vic left me, you remember.

Oh yeah, I remember. She looks around the room and spies a half-eaten lunch on coffee table. The TV plays, muted. For the first time, we get a better look at the room, wit the new curtains. It’s more of a cave now. Some boxes of clothes (Paul’s) s in a corner of the room, like a hoarder’s starter kit. Excuse me? INT. MARTIN’S ROOM Martin gets a gym bag from his closet and begins to stuff various articles of clothing from his chest of drawers. The raised voices of Sophie and Rebecca can be heard thro the walls and down the hall as Martin packs.
--and once again, I am here by myself, trying to do it all on my own without any help--
Help? Is that your code word for making someone listen to you complain about your life all day?
Listen here, Rebecca Ann--  25.
Martin crosses from his bedroom to the bathroom across th hall, hefting his gym bag with him.
Answer the question!

You’re not my doctor, you’re my daughter, why can’t you just be on my side for once-- Martin emerges with his toothbrush in one hand. He heads back for the living room, glancing into-- A HOME OFFICE, its door halfway open. Martin stops. Curious. This is a room that is typically closed to him. Down the hall, the fight continues.

How about you be on Martin’s side, have you thought about that? Martin slowly approaches the door, to peer inside... POV: A SHADOW on the wall moves. Something’s in there. Startled, Martin hurries for the living room. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM Mother and daughter still go at it.
Are you seriously accusing me of being a bad mother? You of all people?
Can we talk about Martin without you jumping to that idea? Come on!
Excuse me for being upset that I have to raise him without his father. Look how you turned out. This cuts Rebecca deep. If she lets it fester, she’ll sta crying. Instead, she hardens up.  26.

I’m going to give you some time. And when you aren’t totally manic, you can call me. Until then, I’m not letting Martin stay here. (calling) Martin, pack your-- Martin steps in, tense, carrying his bag and backpack.
I’m ready. Sophie is shocked.
Martin. Honey. Come on now. Rebecca is now empowered again. Authoritative.
Let's go. Rebecca leads Martin out the front door. Sophie is hot on their tracks.
You two planned this! Didn’t you!
Nobody planned anything, mom. Martin looks back at his mother with a gentle look of pur sympathy. On his way out:

I’ll be back soon as I can. (halfway out the door) Take your vitamins after dinner! EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Rebecca hurries for Bret’s idling SUV with Martin in tow. Bret meets them at the passenger side--
Whoa whoa--
Get back in, we're leaving.
Where we going?  27.
My place. Bret moves. No questions. At the front door, Sophie calls after Rebecca:

You're just like your father! Already in the SUV, Rebecca turns her full anger toward h mother and starts cursing her, while Bret races to shut t passenger automatic window. It seals up at the last word-

You're just like a crazy b-- EXT. REBECCA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - EVENING Establishing. The sky threatens to rain. The clouds are t color of fresh bruises. INT. REBECCA’S BEDROOM - EVENING Rebecca opens the door for Martin, showing him in like a hop to a hotel suite.

Here we are. You can take the bed tonight. Just stash your stuff wherever. Martin steps in and looks wide-eyed at the posters on the walls. Like he’s on an alien planet. Rebecca watches Martin. Suddenly feels embarrassed.
Or if you prefer the couch... Martin puts his bag on the bed.
No. This is fine.

I’m gonna order some dinner. She gently shuts her door, letting him alone. Martin unzips the gym bag and digs around through the clo inside. He finds what he’s after, and pulls it out--  28. A FLASHLIGHT. He checks the switch, then puts it on the nightstand. INT. REBECCA’S LIVING ROOM Bret pulls Rebecca around to speak to her quietly before gets to the kitchen phone.
Was this your idea?
What do you mean?
Bringing the kid here.
It’s not safe there.
So. You call the lady at the school. That’s what CPS is for. Exactly this.
He’s my brother.
She’s his mother.
So? Bret takes a beat. Watches her carefully.
Becks. Did you do this to help him, or to hurt her? Rebecca crosses her arms. Nostrils flaring. In a scary ev tone, she tells Bret:

You should go now. Bret deflates. He grabs his keys. Staying on Rebecca, all stern face and disappointment... The sound of the front door SHUTTING...  29. And Rebecca slumps, almost caving in on herself. She puts hand over her face and lets out a long breath. INT. REBECCA’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Dark. Then a light clicks on to reveal we’re inside the fridge and Rebecca has just opened the door, peering in.
Let me see what I can put together for you... She grabs some lunchmeat.
How about a sandwich? In the dinette right off the kitchen, Martin sits at the table, in his pajamas. He nods. His hair is wild from a recent bath. Rebecca builds a sandwich for him at the counter.
I know this is a little late for dinner. So. We’1l call it a snack. (then) Crust or no crust?
Crust is fine. (then) Can you make them triangles? Rebecca grins.
Oh, you take after your big sister. She brings the sandwich on a plate to the table and prese it to him. Martin takes a bite. Nods: He approves. Rebecca then notices a HAIRBRUSH on the table.
Mom usually brushes my hair.

Well. I’1l give it a try.  30. Rebecca works on taming Martin’s messy hair while he eats For a moment, the two are actually content as siblings. H feels nurtured, and she feels like a proper caregiver. Then, Martin puts down his sandwich.
Rebecca?
Hmm?
If mom is crazy, does it mean we’re a little crazy too? Rebecca pauses. Unsure how to answer that question. It eats at her conscience.

A bonfire crackles. A bonfire made of clothes, CDs, and other personal effect SOPHIE (younger, exhausted) stands at the fire with a box her feet. She wears a bath robe that she’s been living in the past week, judging by its condition. Next to her, a 10-year-old REBECCA. Big eyes. And scared way children get when a pillar of their life changes.
Is that Daddy’s stuff?
Not anymore. He abandoned it all when he ran off with that little harlot from work. Sophie pulls another shirt out of the box. Holds it in fr of her daughter.
